Literature Review: The concept of social reproduction has been a cornerstone of feminist scholarship, highlighting the invisible labor that sustains capitalist societies. This labor, often referred to as unpaid domestic and care work, is performed by women and is essential to the reproduction of the workforce and the maintenance of social order. The laws that govern this labor are complex and multifaceted, reflecting the power dynamics between men and women, as well as the broader social and economic structures that shape our lives. This literature review will examine the key concepts and theories related to social reproduction, including the work of feminist scholars such as Maria Mies, Mariam Duggan, and Nancy Fraser, as well as the legal and materialist approaches to understanding the regulation of reproductive labor. Social reproduction theory, as outlined by Maria Mies (1986), posits that women's unpaid work is a key site of resistance to capitalist exploitation. Mies argues that women's labor is not only essential to the reproduction of the workforce but also serves as a means of survival and resistance in the face of patriarchal oppression. This theory has been influential in shaping feminist scholarship on unpaid work and has been applied in various contexts, including the analysis of domestic labor and care work. Mariam Duggan's (2015) work on the intersectionality of unpaid work and the law highlights the ways in which laws and policies governing reproductive labor are shaped by power dynamics between men and women. Duggan argues that the law often perpetuates the exploitation of women's labor, reinforcing the notion that unpaid work is a natural and necessary part of women's roles in society. This perspective has been influential in shaping feminist legal theory and has been applied in various contexts, including the analysis of domestic violence and child custody laws. Nancy Fraser's (1997) work on materialist feminism has also been influential in shaping our understanding of social reproduction. Fraser argues that materialist feminism should prioritize the analysis of economic and social structures in understanding the regulation of reproductive labor. This approach has been applied in various contexts, including the analysis of the impact of neoliberal policies on unpaid work and the law. In recent years, the COVID-19 pandemic has rendered visible once again the reproductive labor of women, highlighting the importance of unpaid work in sustaining capitalist societies. The pandemic has also underscored the need for a materialist approach to understanding the regulation of reproductive labor, one that prioritizes the analysis of economic and social structures in understanding the power dynamics between men and women. One key concept in understanding the regulation of reproductive labor is the idea of the 'marriage-market spectrum'. This concept, as outlined by sociologist Arlie Hochschild (1989), refers to the ways in which laws and policies governing reproductive labor are shaped by the power dynamics between men and women in the context of marriage and family. Hochschild argues that the marriage-market spectrum is characterized by a range of power dynamics, from the idealized notion of the 'good wife' to the more nuanced understanding of the ways in which women's labor is shaped by economic and social structures. In terms of legal realism, the work of feminist scholars such as Martha Nussbaum (2006) has been influential in shaping our understanding of the regulation of reproductive labor. Nussbaum argues that the law often fails to recognize the value of unpaid work and the ways in which it is essential to the reproduction of the workforce and the maintenance of social order. This perspective has been applied in various contexts, including the analysis of domestic violence and child custody laws. In conclusion, the laws that govern reproductive labor are complex and multifaceted, reflecting the power dynamics between men and women, as well as the broader social and economic structures that shape our lives. A materialist approach to understanding the regulation of reproductive labor, one that prioritizes the analysis of economic and social structures in understanding the power dynamics between men and women, is essential in developing a more just and equitable society. By examining the key concepts and theories related to social reproduction, including the work of feminist scholars such as Maria Mies, Mariam Duggan, and Nancy Fraser, we can gain a deeper understanding of the ways in which laws and policies governing reproductive labor are shaped by power dynamics and economic and social structures.
